disease.title: Abrasion
disease.description2:
Superficial wounds affecting only the topmost skin layer.
Clean the Wound: Wash with clean water and mild soap to remove dirt and debris.
Stop Bleeding: Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth if there's minor bleeding.
Soothe the Area (Optional): Apply antibiotic ointment to prevent infection (check with a doctor for allergies).
Cover and Monitor: Bandage the scrape to prevent further irritation and watch for signs of infection (redness, pus, fever).
Remember: Don't use harsh chemicals or scrub the wound. See a doctor for deep scrapes, severe bleeding, or embedded objects.

disease.title: Lacteration
disease.description2:
Deeper cuts involving multiple skin layers or underlying tissue.
Stop Bleeding: Apply firm pressure with a clean cloth directly on the wound.
Clean the Wound (Optional, for minor cuts): If bleeding slows, gently clean with cool water and mild soap (avoid scrubbing). 
Elevate (if possible): Raise the injured area above the heart to reduce swelling.
Bandage: Cover the wound with a sterile bandage to protect it from dirt and infection

disease.title: Bruises
disease.description2:
Bleeding and swelling under the skin caused by blunt trauma.
Rest: Avoid strenuous activity on the bruised area.
Ice: Apply ice packs (wrapped in a cloth) to the bruise for 15-20 minutes at a time, several times a day to reduce swelling.
Compression: Use an elastic bandage to provide gentle compression and minimize further swelling.
Elevation: Elevate the bruised area above the heart whenever possible to reduce swelling.

disease.title: Ankle Sprain
disease.description2:
An ankle sprain is a stretching or tearing of the ligaments, the tough tissues that connect bones at a joint, in the ankle. It's a very common injury, especially among athletes and people who are physically active. 

Symptoms: 

Pain, especially when you bear weight on the affected foot 

Tenderness when you touch the ankle 

Swelling 

Bruising 

Restricted range of motion 

Instability in the ankle 

Popping sensation or sound at the time of injury

disease.title: Traumatic Brain Injury
disease.description2:
Check ABCs: Ensure Airway is open, control Bleeding with pressure, and assess their Consciousness (alertness). 

Clean the Wound: Gently wash the wound with cool water and mild soap to remove dirt and debris. 

Apply Antibiotic Ointment: Apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment to reduce the risk of infection. 

Cover the Wound: Protect the wound with a sterile bandage or gauze pad. 

Change Dressings: Change the bandage daily or as needed to keep the wound clean and dry. 

Monitor: Watch for signs of infection, such as increased pain, redness, or pus. Seek medical help if needed. 

Remember: Don't pick at scabs, as this can slow healing and increase the risk of infection.

disease.title: Scalp Injury
disease.description2:
A scalp injury is a cut, scrape, or bruise on the hairy part of your head.  Here's a quick rundown of first aid: 

Control Bleeding: Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth to slow bleeding. 

Clean the Wound: Once bleeding slows, clean the wound with clean water and mild soap. 

Bandage (Optional): If needed, use a sterile bandage to cover the wound. 

Monitor: Watch for signs of infection like redness, pus, or fever. See a doctor if these appear. 

Remember: 

Don’t use harsh chemicals or scrub the wound. 

Seek medical attention for deep cuts, severe bleeding, or if debris is stuck in the wound.

disease.title: Jaw Injuries
disease.description2:
A jaw injury involves damage to the jawbone, teeth, or jaw joint. Here's a quick first-aid response: 

Control Bleeding: Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth to slow bleeding. 

Don’t Realign: Leave the jaw as you find it. Attempts to move it can worsen the injury. 

Reduce Swelling: Apply ice packs (wrapped in cloth) to the jaw to minimize pain and swelling. 

Support the Jaw: If possible, use a sling to gently support the jaw and minimize movement. 

Seek Medical Help: See a doctor as soon as possible for proper diagnosis and treatment

disease.title: CPR
disease.description2:
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is a lifesaving technique that's useful in many emergencies in which someone's breathing or heartbeat has stopped. The American Heart Association recommends that everyone — untrained bystanders and medical personnel alike — begin CPR with chest compressions. It's far better to do something than to do nothing at all if you're fearful that your knowledge or abilities aren't 100 percent complete. Remember, the difference between your doing something and doing nothing could be someone's life. Here's a quick rundown of CPR and First Aid for bystanders: 
First Check: 
. Unresponsive: Gently shake and ask if they're okay. 
If Unresponsive: 
. Push & Breathe (if trained): If trained in CPR, begin chest compressions (30) followed by 2 rescue breaths. Repeat cycles until help arrives. 
. Hands-Only CPR (alternative): If not CPR trained, do continuous chest compressions (push hard & fast) in the center of the chest until help arrives.

disease.title: Compound Fracture
disease.description2:
A compound fracture (also known as an “open fracture”) is a bone fracture that is accompanied by breaks in the skin, causing the broken ends of bone to come into contact with the outside environment. This can lead to infection and other complications.
First Aid (DON'T ATTEMPT TO RESET THE BONE):
Control Bleeding: Apply gentle pressure to the wound with a clean cloth.
Minimize Movement: Stabilize the injured area with something splint-like (e.g., cardboard, rolled magazine) to prevent further movement.
Cover the Wound: Place a sterile bandage (or clean cloth) over the wound without applying pressure directly to the bone.
Remember: Don't try to push the bone back in, clean the wound extensively, or give food or drink. Leave that to medical professionals.
